results.title: Date with history: Hiroshima
results.brief_description: Shows the preliminary events leading up to the bombing of Hiroshima in August, 1945 in which 72,000 people were killed. some of the people involved are interviewed, giving their reactions to the holocaust. The film contains actual footage of the events.

results.title: Date with Dizzy
results.creator_credit: Jim Di Gangi, Hubley Films and John Hubley
results.brief_description: A gentle satire on television commercials showing the production and use of effective advertising. Features Dizzy Gillespie and Quintet improvising a musical soundtrack for drawings made by John Hubley and his staff as they create animated-cartoon television commercials for a new product with unsuccessful results until the director screens three previous advertisements as examples of the desired effect. Concludes with a wild jam session led by Dizzy Gillespie. Several of the Hubley animation techniques are illustrated making this film useful for discussion on film technique.

results.title: Date of birth
results.creator_credit: Michael Spencer, ONF | NFB and Donald Fraser
results.brief_description: A tribute to the older worker’s high standard of dependability and productivity, and a plea to employers to remove age barriers in hiring new staff. The bitter disappointment felt by an able man denied work because he is over forty-five is expressed in a brief dramatic sequence, and then the film presents the actual record of employees in this age group, reminding us that there is less absenteeism, a lower turnover rate and an equal standard of production among older workers. The importance to the whole country of giving a fair chance to workers over forty-five years of age is explained, and ways in which their problem is being tackled are described.

results.title: Data processing: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Dick Larson
results.brief_description: Introduces the basic data processing functions of sorting data, collating material and calculating, beginning with manual methods and moving into punched card equipment. With electronic computer systems, we learn ways of increasing the speed and flexibility of processing, resulting in faster ways of handling greater quantities of data.

results.title: Data panic!
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Close to trillion dollars a day changes hands globally in foreign exchange transactions. Only 15 percent corresponds to actual commodities or capital. The incredible speed of the New York Stock Exchange’s Superdot electronic order routing system means that the Dow Jones can swing back and forth by more than 50 points in a matter of minutes. These conditions bring about a condition known as “data panic” a feeling of insecurity and anxiety that engulfs every transfer of digital information, from international trade to electronic banking.

Data Panic combines images of computers, tape streamers, ATMs, terminals, workstations, printers, status indicators, traces and scans with computer animated icons, diagrams, pictograms, error messages, warnings, numbers, barcodes and binary digits. An advertorial style voice over narrates a non-sensical computer generated text interspersed with information technology advertising slogans.

results.title: Data for decision
results.creator_credit: Sidney Goldsmith, ONF | NFB and David Millar
results.brief_description: A look at the ‘Canada Land Inventory Geo-information System’, a computer system used to help manage and develop Canadian land. Shows the computer’s capacity for storing information, correlating and interpreting facts, and converting data into maps and diagrams. Photographed by Martin Duckworth, Jacques Foges and Kjeld Nielsen; animation by Donald Stearn; edited by Arthur Lipsett; sound by Sidney Pearson and George Croll; narrated by Richard Gilbert.

results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films

Episode of Series “Athletics”.

results.title: Das Rheingold
results.creator_credit: Otto Schenk, Metropolitan Opera (New York, N.Y.), La Sept, Channel 4, Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen, Deutsche Grammophon and Brian Large
results.brief_description: In the first opera in Richard Wagner’s massive Ring Cycle, the Rhinegold is stolen by Alberich from the Rhine maidens and later fashioned into a ring of power, thus setting in train the saga which culminates in Die Gotterdammerung. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus is conducted by James Levine and the cast includes Christa Ludwig, Ekkehard Wlaschina, and James Morris. Sung in German, the video is accompanied by a synopsis. Wagner’s Ring Cycle consists of four parts, in this order: Das Rheingold; Die Walkuere; Siegfried and Goetterdaemmerung.
